abstract: Farmers in Southern California are often paid to keep their fields idle in order to free up water for thirsty cities and suburbs, but process has negative effect on labor markets and economies of rural towns (Series: Precious Waters).
snippet: With water increasingly scarce in the West, a new program is allowing some farmers to sell their allotment of it for whatever price they can find, but it comes with a hitch.
lead_paragraph: With water increasingly scarce in the West, a new program is allowing some farmers to sell their allotment of it for whatever price they can find, but it comes with a hitch.

headline.main: Empty Fields Fill Urban Basins and Farmers’ Pockets
headline.print_headline: Empty Fields Fill Urban Basins and Farmers’ Pockets
headline.seo: To Get Water to Cities, California Farmers Paid Not to Plant
